lesson.name: Unit 4: Part 2: Focus on the Students

page.title: Overview
page.contents:
A growing proportion of the workforce will encounter work situations that pose unforeseen problems that they need to resolve.

(Reder, 2015, p.3).

Digital literacy and problem-solving skills are important for work, school, and community. Research has demonstrated that these skills are connected to wages, political participation, and health.

Adult English language learners need strong digital literacy and problem-solving skills. Teachers and program administrators can help ELLs develop these skills by integrating digital activities across the curriculum, in all types of programs, in every subject, and at every level.

English language learners face challenges in problem solving in technology-rich environments; these challenges include language skills, digital literacy skills, and unfamiliarity with the way that technologies are used in different settings and for different purposes.

page.title: Problem Solving
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-31.mp3

Audio transcript


Imagine that a student in one of your adult English-language-acquisition classes had the following problem. We will call it the Parent-Teacher-Conference Problem.

Late one afternoon, the woman’s son told her that she had to go to his parent–teacher conference that night. He didn’t know what time or where she should go but knew that she needed to attend. The woman was willing to attend, but she didn’t know how to find out where she should go and the time of the conference. The school was already closed, and so she could not call on the phone. This example will be used several times in this unit.

This was a technology-rich environment because, at this school, communication between teachers and parents occurred primarily through a class blog, text, and e-mail. Communication between the school and families happened on the school website, which included the school calendar. The problem presented a variety of difficulties for the mother.

There are five basic steps to solving problems in technology-rich environments:

  1. Understand the nature of the problem.

  2. Make a plan.

  3. Monitor progress.

  4. Select information.

  5. Make use of the information.

The Parent–Teacher Conference Problem

page.title: Understand the Nature of the Problem
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-32.mp3

Audio transcript


The easiest way to think about the first step in problem solving is to consider a problem that provides a context. Our sample problem is called the Buying-a-Computer Problem, and it will be referenced several times in this unit.

These are the particulars: A student in your class wants to buy a computer for her family to use. Her children need it for their schoolwork, and she wants to use it for her own learning. She wants to get Internet access, also, but is worried about the cost; money spent on a computer and spent on Internet access will mean less money available for rent, groceries, and gas. She would like to get the computer and Internet access before the next school term, which starts in 5 weeks.

Understanding the nature of the problem includes identifying goals. In this example, the student has two goals, to identify the lowest cost computer and to identify the lowest cost Internet. A second part of understanding the nature of the problem is predicting what the solution might look like. In this case, your student can predict that the solution will probably include the brand of a computer, the cost of the computer, where to buy the computer, the name and cost of Internet service, and how to sign up for Internet. Predicting what a solution might look like takes practice and is likely to involve cultural assumptions. When you design your own problem-solving lesson, think about what your students can do with the funds of knowledge that they have as adults, as well as what they need to learn.


The Buying-a-Computer Problem: A student in your class wants to buy a computer for her family to use. Her children need it for their schoolwork, and she wants to use it for her own learning. She wants to get Internet access, also, but is worried about the cost; money spent on a computer and on Internet access will mean less money available for rent, groceries, and gas. She would like to get the computer and Internet access before the next school term, which starts in 5 weeks.

Understanding the nature of the problem includes

  • Identifying goals

  • Predicting what the solution may look like

In the example provided (box at right), the student has at least two goals:

  • Identifying the lowest cost computer

  • Identifying the lowest cost Internet access

She can predict that the solution will include

  • The name of a computer

  • The cost of the computer

  • Where to buy the computer

  • The name and cost of Internet service

  • How to sign up for Internet

page.title: Make a Plan
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-33.mp3

Audio transcript


There are three steps in making a plan: (1) identifying the resources available, such as Internet tools; other technologies; and nontechnical resources, such as people to talk to; (2) determining the amount of time that can be spent on finding a solution and the deadline for solving the problem; and (3) designing the format for the solution. In our example, Buying-a- Computer Problem, the resources include searching the Internet, talking to people at the school, and asking friends for advice. The time line is already set out in the problem—the computer and Internet service need to be purchased and ready within 5 weeks. Thinking about formats is very helpful in problem solving. In this case a table or spreadsheet can be helpful for collecting information and comparing it.

Making a plan includes

  • Identifying the resources available, such as Internet tools, other technologies, and nontechnical resources (e.g., people )

  • Determining the amount of time that can be spent on finding a solution and the deadline for solving the problem

  • Designing the format for the solution

For example, in the Buying-a-Computer Problem, resources include Internet searching, people at the school, and friends.

Since the student wants to resolve the problem within 5 weeks, it is important for her start right away.

A spreadsheet or table to compare the results of the search may be a useful format for the solution.

page.title: Select Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-34.mp3

Audio transcript


Selecting information includes making reasoned guesses about where information is and how to locate it. While much of the search will be on the Internet, there may be other resources to use, such as print resources, a community expert, or the librarian at the local library. Selecting information also involves assessing the relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias, or perspective, of the information and its source. In the Buying-a-Computer Problem, selected information may include websites that are judged to be reputable sellers of computers. Who is considered reputable is an important question and may be more important than English language learners are used to. For example, Craigslist or other online individual sellers may not be reputable sources for computers.

Selecting information includes searching for the information required to solve the problem. Much of the search will be on the Internet, but there may be other resources used, as well.

Selecting information includes making reasoned guesses about where information is and how to locate it.

Selecting information also involves assessing the relevance, accuracy, reliability, and bias or perspective of the information and its source.

page.title: Make Use of the Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-35.mp3

Audio transcript


In this step, the students use the information to consider the different options and select the most viable solution, often organizing or reorganizing the information. This step is especially useful for the English-language-acquisition process. By this point in the lesson or unit, students will be familiar with the topic and the language used in the activity. Using the information that they have selected, students organize it or transform it into a different format. This is good for fluency building, language practice, and digital literacy. For example, students may make a spreadsheet of the computer prices, qualities, and dates available, or make a table that includes the different jobs available, the responsibilities, pay, and travel distance.

Making use of the information involves organizing the information that helps to reach a solution.

This step is especially useful for the English- language-acquisition process. Using the information that they have selected, students organize it or transform it into a different format. This is good for fluency building, language practice, and digital literacy.

For example, students may make a spreadsheet of the computer prices, qualities, and dates available, or a table that includes the different jobs available, the responsibilities, pay, and travel distance.

In this step, the students use the information to consider the different options and select the most viable solution.

page.title: Make Use of the Information 2
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U4_Slide-35B.mp3

Audio transcript


Sometimes solving a problem includes communicating with other people about the solution. If that is the case, then this communication is part of the solution. As an English language teacher you are accustomed to helping students learn language needed to accomplish a task, and this is another such case. Depending on the problem and the lesson or unit that it relates to, the students may do one of many different things, including

-Write an e-mail to the teacher about a missed parent–teacher conference
-Make a PowerPoint presentation detailing the best computer to buy and Internet service to get -Add selected job search websites to a blog documenting the job search process

If making use of the information is part of the problem, this step also includes communicating with relevant people to convey the solution reached.

There are many different ways that the students can communicate the information. What is appropriate depends on the curriculum unit and the students.

The students may

  • Write an e-mail to the teacher about a missed parent–teacher conference

  • Make a PowerPoint presentation detailing the best computer to buy and Internet service to get

  • Add selected job search websites to a blog documenting the job search process
